document.docAuthor: Mori, Shinnosuke & Hasegawa, Yoichi & Moriguchi, Yoshinari
document.docTitle: Color strategies of camellias recruiting different pollinators

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Color strategies of camellias recruiting different pollinators

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Science and Technology, Keio University, 3-14-1 Hiyoshi, Kohoku-ku, Yokohama, 223-8522, Japan

paragraph.docTitle: Color strategies of camellias recruiting different pollinators

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Science and Technology, Keio University, 3-14-1 Hiyoshi, Kohoku-ku, Yokohama, 223-8522, Japan

paragraph.emphasis: Forestry and Forest Products Research Institute , Forest Research and Management Organization , 1 Matsunosato , Tsukuba , Ibaraki , 305-8687, Japan
Graduate School of Science and Technology, Niigata University, 8050, Ikarashi 2-Nocho, Nishi-ku, Niigata , 950-2181, Japan

subSection.paragraph: A R T I C L E I N F O
Camellia rusticana Honda Camellia japonica L. Theaceae
Snow camellia
Japanese camellia Pollinator shift
Pollination syndrome
Bee avoidance hypothesis Anthranilate
A B S T R A C T

Most ornithophilous plants have red flowers; this has been associated with ‘the bee avoidance hypothesis’, in which ornithophilous flowers may bear colors that are less conspicuous to bees than melittophilous flowers. In the genus
Camellia
,
C. rusticana
and
C. japonica
bear red flowers and yet recruit different pollinators; the former is entomophilous, while the latter is ornithophilous.
C. japonica
is considered to have been speciated from a common ancestor later than
C. rusticana
, accompanying a pollinator shift from insects to birds. Nevertheless, factors explaining the pollinator difference in camellias remain rudimentary. In this study, the color traits of the two camellias were investigated, to determine their color strategy to allure different pollinators.

The behavior of bees towards the two camellias was examined by a two-choice assay. Flower color characteristics of the two camellias were analyzed with diffuse reflectance and fluorescence spectra. Based on the visual sensory system of bees and birds, the achromatic contrast, chromatic contrast, intensity, and spectral purity of the two species were evaluated, testing the bee avoidance hypothesis. Furthermore, the compounds responsible for the fluorescence, likely serving as a visual attractant, were identified by NMR and MS.

Bees visited
C. rusticana
flowers almost exclusively and
C. japonica
hardly at all. Reflectance spectral data showed that
C. rusticana
petals are more conspicuous to bees than birds due to a UV-reflection secondary peak; and that
C. japonica
petals exhibited crucially low chromatic contrast against a leaf background to bees, suggesting them to be almost indistinguishable. On the other hand,
C. japonica
flowers appeared conspicuous to birds. The anthers of
C. rusticana
exhibited blue fluorescence derived from two anthranilates, while those of
C. japonica
did not.

The two camellias offer different color strategies to be conspicuous to their respective pollinators, and
C. japonica
seemed to have evolved to avoid bees. Alterations in these color traits may have played a role in pollinator shift.
* Corresponding author.
E-mail address: mori.shinnosuke.72x@kyoto-u.jp (S. Mori).

Since pollinators possess different visual systems from human beings, it should be noted that they sense so-called red differently from human observers. “Red” flowers have categorized into three types based on the reflectance spectrum by Chittka and Waser (1997) : with a secondary peak at UV region, with that at blue region, and without secondary peak. Lunau et al. (2011) unveiled that red melittophilous flowers reflect more UV than red trochilophilous (hummingbird -pollinated) flowers in neotropical plants. Red ornithophilous flowers, which lack a secondary reflectance peak at shorter wavelengths, therefore appear inconspicuous to bees ( Chen et al., 2020 ).

In testing the bee avoidance hypothesis,
Camellia (Theaceae)
is potential model plants.
Camellia
is an evergreen shrub native to the temperate zone in south-eastern and eastern Asia and China . The genus contains more than 250 species, including economically important tea trees, edible oil sources, and ornamental flowers, in which great diversity of floral traits has been found. In Japan ,
Camellia rusticana Honda
(the snow camellia; Fig. 1A ) and
Camellia japonica
L. (the Japanese camellia; Fig. 1I ) are naturally distributed.
C. japonica
is widely distributed in Japan except in Hokkaido ( Fig. S1 ), and blooms from November to April.
C. rusticana
is distributed along areas of the coast of the Japan Sea having heavy snowfall ( Fig. S1 ; Hagiya and Ishizawa, 1961 ), and its flowers appear a little later than
C. japonica
, from April to May. The populations of
C. rusticana
are located at elevations ranging from 295 to 1429 m , and those of
C. japonica
from 8 to 781 m elevation ( Abe et al., 2021 ; Hagiya and Ishizawa, 1961 ).
C. rusticana
and
C. japonica
are therefore ecologically segregated, but can bear an introgressive hybridized species
C. × intermedia
when their habitats are in close proximity ( Fig. 1E ; Hagiya and Ishizawa, 1961 ).

The taxonomic classification of
C. rusticana
and
C. japonica
has been discussed for decades and regarded as either a variety, subspecies, or species ( Abe et al., 2021 ); but several studies reported their different morphological, physiological, and ecological characteristics. Hagiya and Ishizawa (1961) reported morphological differences between the two species, including their differing numbers of sepals, petals, stamens and stigma splits; shapes of petal and leaf. A recent comparative analysis of flower morphology found that the petals of
C. japonica
has larger size, higher saturation, and lower brightness in the visible range of humans ( 400–700 nm ) than those of
C. rusticana ( Abe et al., 2021 )
. The anthocyanin profiles of their petals also differ, which likely contributes to the different colors of their petals ( Sakata et al., 1986 ). Furthermore, the stamens of
C. japonica
are coalesced into a closed tube, while those of
C. rusticana
are free-standing ( Abe et al., 2021 ). Although more detailed analyses are required for a comprehensive understanding of phylogeny and evolution of
Camellia
, previous studies have concluded that
C. rusticana
speciated from a common ancestor earlier than
C. japonica
by analyses of their petal pigments, isozymes, morphology, and molecular phylogeny based on nrITS sequences ( Sakata et al., 1987 ; Eguchi et al., 1991 ; Tuyama, 1996 ; Vijayan et al., 2009 ).

Their pollination vectors are also different. Pollination of
C. rusticana
is mainly carried out by insects such as bees, flies, and small beetles ( Ishizawa, 1988 ), but not birds. On the other hand,
C. japonica
is primarily pollinated by a small passerine, the Japanese white-eye (
Zosterops japonicus
), a UVS-type bird ( Odeen and Hastad, 2010 ) in Japan ( Kunitake et al., 2004 ).
Z. japonicus
is also the most frequent visitor to
C. japonica
in Korea ( Rho and Choe, 2003 ). The large petal and coalesced stamens of
C. japonica
are also well-suited to the foraging abilities of
Z. japonicus
, and may be an example of bird pollination syndrome ( Cronk and Ojeda, 2008 ).
C. chekiangoleosa
, native to China , is considered to be a species closely related to
C. rusticana
and more ancestral than
C. japonica
( Tuyama, 1996 ; Vijayan et al., 2009 ).
C. chekiangoleosa
is also entomophilous, as is
C. rusticana
; a pollinator shift from insects to birds is assumed to have been occurred, driving the speciation of
C. japonica
. Indeed, evolutionary shifts from melittophily to ornithophily are confirmed in several genera (eg.,
Penstemon
,
Mimulus
,
Ipomoea
,
Costus
,
Aquilegia
,
Silene
, and
Salvia
; reviewed in Thomson and Wilson, 2008 ). Entomophilous and ornithophilous flowers often have differences in primary (i.e., nectar, pollen) and/or secondary attractants (i.e., visual and olfactory cues, etc.) ( Fenster et al., 2004 ). We presumed that the bee avoidance mechanism and fluorescence participate as visual factors in the pollinator difference between
C. rusticana
and
C. japonica
.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 1. Photographs of the flowers and anthers. (A , B) Flower of
Camellia rusticana
and (C, D) its anther; (E, F) flower of
C. × intermedia
and (G , H) its anther; and (I, J) flower of
C. japonica
and (K, L) its anther under white light ( left ) and UV 365 nm ( right ). Scale bars, 10 mm for (A, E, I) and 1 mm for (C, G, K) . [color in online only]. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)

subSection.paragraph:
In this study, we experimentally explored the bee avoidance hypothesis. First, we conducted a bumblebee behavioral assay with
C. rusticana
and
C. japonica
flowers, showing the contribution of secondary attractants rather than the primary attractants. We then explored the flower color characteristics encompassing reflectance and fluorescence that underlies the difference in their pollinators. Diffuse reflectance spectra for both species were collected; color parameters in these camellias were analyzed based on the visual models of bee and UVSavian, testing the bee avoidance hypothesis. We also characterized the fluorescence properties of the two species and identified the compounds responsible.

heading.emphasis: 2.1. Flower-visiting behavior of bumblebees to camellias

subSection.paragraph:
In the two-choice test between
C. rusticana
and
C. japonica
,
B. ignitus
preferentially visited
C. rusticana
[25.8 ± 4.3 vs 1.1 ± 1.1 (visits/10 min);
p <
0.01] ( Fig. 2 ). The flowers of
C. rusticana
had 20–33 visits/10 min, whereas
C. japonica
was visited in only five out of eight tests, with a maximum of 3 visits/10 min. In the
C. rusticana
vs
C. rusticana
test, the bumblebees visited the two plants equally (15.6 ± 2.1 vs 16.4 ± 1.5; p = 0.43). In the
C. japonica
vs
C. japonica
test, both plants were visited rarely (0.4 ± 0.5 vs 0.6 ± 0.7; p = 0.45), corresponding to only 0–3 visits/10 min, even though the bees were flying out of the hive. This result indicates that the bumblebees chose
C. rusticana
from a distance based on visual and/or olfactory cues, before accessing rewards (i.e., nectar, pollen) and experiencing a tactile cue.

The differences in the colors of the anthers, petals, and leaves of
C. rusticana
and
C. japonica
were examined by measuring their diffuse reflectance spectra ( Fig. 3 ). The reflectance spectra of the leaves were similar, and therefore their average was used as a leaf background in the following section, Visual Perceptual Color Space of Pollinators . The spectra of the anthers of the two species were also similar. In contrast, the spectra of their petals differed radically in the UV-A range; the petal of
C. rusticana
has a secondary peak at 347 nm , whereas that of
C. japonica
absorbs UV. The secondary peak ratio, k , was 0.27 ± 0.00 for
C. rusticana
and 0.13 ± 0.00 for
C. japonica
(
p <
0.01). The AUCRef in the UV range ( 300–400 nm ) was 2.4-fold higher in the petal of
C. rusticana
than that of
C. japonica
(1191.1 vs 489.3;
p <
0.01).

heading.emphasis: 2.3. Visual perceptual color space of pollinators

subSection.paragraph:
The color loci of the petal and anther of
C. rusticana
and
C. japonica
in the color spaces of each pollinator are depicted in Fig. 4 , based on the visual systems of bees and birds. All color parameters in the CH and RNL models are summarized in Table 1 .

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 3. Reflectance of the camellia flowers. Diffuse reflectance spectra of the petal, anther, and leaf of
Camellia rusticana
( r ) and
C. japonica
( j ). Arrows below the spectra indicate the visible range of bees and UVS-birds. [color in online only]. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)

Fig. 2. Flower-visiting behavior of bumblebees to camellias. Bee visits per 10 min in
Camellia rusticana
vs
C. rusticana
,
C. rusticana
vs
C. japonica
, and
C. japonica
vs
C. japonica
. White line, median; whiskers, max and min; circle, outliers. *
p <
0.01; ns, not significant (
p >
0.05) in unpaired t -test (n = 8 for each match). [color in online only]. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)

subSection.paragraph:
According to the color loci in the bee color hexagon, the petal and anther of both species were classified as UV–Blue and Green, respectively ( Fig. 4A ). The color category of the petals did not change, regardless of whether a secondary peak was present. Significant differences were detected between the two species for all color parameters in both petal and anther (
p >
0.05). The UV-reflecting petal of
C. rusticana
displayed higher achromatic contrast, chromatic contrast, intensity, and spectral purity, compared to the UV-absorbing petal of
C. japonica
. In
C. rusticana
, the anther also presented significantly greater values in achromatic contrast and intensity than that of
C. japonica
.

In the UVS-avian tetrahedral color space, the loci of
C. japonica
were located closer to the tetrahedral vertex related to the red receptor ( Fig. 4B ). In contrast to the bee color hexagon, the petal and anther of
C. japonica
had significantly higher Δ S and spectral purity than those of
C. rusticana
( Table 1 ). Achromatically,
C. japonica
had petals with lower contrast than
C. rusticana
(14.07 vs 11.73,
p <
0.01) and anthers with no significant difference in the pairwise comparison (16.97 vs 16.73, p = 0.30).

The anther and pollen of the three species were found to fluoresce differently under UV irradiation of 365 nm ( Fig. 1 ). The outermost anther wall of
C. rusticana
and
C. × intermedia
was observed to emit blue fluorescence ( Fig. 1D, H ), whereas that of
C. japonica
was not ( Fig. 1L ); the anther wall of all species appeared to be colorless under white light. The yellow pollen grains of all species did not display fluorescence.

The excitation and emission maxima of the anthers of both plants were 353 nm and 427 nm , respectively ( Fig. 5A ). The anther of
C. × intermedia
was less fluorescent than that of
C. rusticana
. The AUCEm of
C. rusticana
anthers was 7.1-fold and 2.8-fold higher than that of
C. japonica
and
C. × intermedia
, respectively ( Fig. 5B ).

The major fluorescent compounds isolated from the extract of
C. rusticana
anther were identified as 1-
O
-β- D-glucopyranosyl anthranilate ( 1 ) and methyl anthranilate ( 2 ) ( Fig. 6 ), based on 1 H NMR and ESI-TOF MS spectral analyses ( Parada et al., 1996 ). The amounts of 1 and
2 in
the anther are shown in Fig. 7 and were present in significantly higher in
C. rusticana
compared to the other two species (
p <
0.01). The anthers contained 1 of 4.4 ± 0.3 mg g 1 FW for
C. rusticana
, 2.5 ± 0.3 mg g 1 FW for
C. × intermedia
, and 0.1 ± 0.04 mg g 1 FW for
C. japonica
; and 2 of 0.05 ± 0.01 mg g 1 FW for
C. rusticana
, 0.007 ± 0.002 mg g 1 FW for
C. × intermedia
, and 0.006 ± 0.003 mg g 1 FW for
C. japonica
.

caption.paragraph:
Comparison of the color variables of
Camellia rusticana
and
C. japonica
according to the visual system of bees and UVS-birds.

paragraph.tableNote:
Mean ± SD (n = 3 for each). p values from unpaired Student’ s t -test [ t ( Chittka, 1992 )]. *
p <
0.05, **
p <
0.01. ns, not significant (
p >
0.05).

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 5. Fluorescence of the anthers and fluorescent compounds. ( A ) Excitation (dashed line) and emission spectra (solid line) of the intrinsic anthers. ( B ) Area under the curve of emission spectra ( AUCEm ). Mean ± SD (n = 3 for each). One-way ANOVA,
p <
0.01. Different letters denote significant differences (
p <
0.05) in post-hoc test (Tukey–Kramer). ( c ) Excitation (dashed line) and emission spectra (solid line) of 1- O -β- D-glucopyranosyl anthranilate ( 1 ), methyl anthranilate ( 2 ), and anthranilic acid ( A ) in MeOH. [color in online only]. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)

subSection.paragraph:
The fluorescence spectrum of 1 and
2 in
MeOH showed the following maxima of excitation ( λ Ex ) and emission ( λ Em ): 359 nm and 419 nm ( 1 ); and 386 nm and 408 nm ( 2 ), respectively ( Fig. 5C ). Anthranilic acid exhibited λ Ex at 332 nm and λ Em at 405 nm , indicating that anthranilate is the fluorophore of 1 and 2 .

caption.paragraph: Fig. 6. Chemical structure of the isolated fluorescent compounds. 1- O -β- D- Glucopyranosyl anthranilate ( 1 ) and methyl anthranilate ( 2 ).

subSection.paragraph:
The bee behavior in the two-choice assay clearly indicates that visual and/or olfactory cues are responsible for the preference of the bees for
C. rusticana
over
C. japonica
, which can be accounted for with reference to differences in the reflectance and fluorescence of the petals and anthers of the two species.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 7. Amounts of the fluorescent compounds in the anthers. ( A ) 1- O -β- D-Glucopyranosyl anthranilate ( 1 ). ( B ) Methyl anthranilate ( 2 ). FW, fresh weight. Mean ± SD (n = 3). One-way ANOVA,
p <
0.01. Different letters denote significant differences (
p <
0.05) in post-hoc test (Tukey–Kramer). [color in online only]. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)

subSection.paragraph:
C. rusticana
petals are UV-reflecting red, whereas those of
C. japonica
are UV-absorbing red. The secondary peak ratio, k , of
C. rusticana
(0.27 ± 0.00) was almost consistent with the mean k of melittophilous red flowers reported in Chen et al. (2020) . The k value of
C. japonica
(0.13 ± 0.00) was similar to the lowest k of ornithophilous flowers in the Old World ( Chen et al., 2020 ). Although it is difficult for humans to distinguish the petal colors of these two species, they would appear radically different to bees and birds. This reflectance difference between entomophilous
C. rusticana
and passerine-pollinated
C. japonica
is consistent with previous studies comparing melittophilous and ornithophilous flowers ( Lunau et al., 2011 ; Chen et al., 2020 ). Besides, Lunau et al. (2011) demonstrated that the orchid bee (
Euglossa viridissima
) preferred UV-reflecting over UV-absorbing red stimuli in the two-choice experiment. Since bees lack red-sensitive photoreceptors ( Peitsch et al., 1992 ), they have difficulty detecting UV-absorbing red colors of
C. japonica
than red-sensitive
Z. japonicus
. The secondary reflectance peak in the UV region seemed to be an essential component for attracting bees.

In the bee perception, achromatic contrasts mediate detection and discrimination at distances, rather than chromatic contrasts ( Giurfa et al., 1996 ; Dotterl and Vereecken, 2010 ). However, at shorter distances, chromatic contrast is activated ( Dyer et al., 2008 ). The secondary peak provided
C. rusticana
petals greater contrasts both achromatically (0.103 ± 0.007 hex units) and chromatically (0.129 ± 0.001 hex units) than
C. japonica
( Table 1 ), which enable
C. rusticana
to be more conspicuous to bees at both short and long distances. Behavioral experiments have shown that bees can detect colored targets with a chromatic contrast ≥0.1 hex units; targets whose chromatic contrast is lower appear achromatic ( Chittka et al., 1993 , 1994 ). The UV-absorbing properties of
C. japonica
petals decrease their chromatic contrast below 0.1 (0.080 ± 0.011 hex units), suggesting the petals of this plant to be almost indistinguishable to bees from the leaves. The spectral purity ( Lunau et al., 1996 ) and intensity ( Hempel de Ibarra et al., 2000 ) also affect the attractiveness to bees; these parameters of the UV-reflecting petals of
C. rusticana
are significantly higher than those of
C. japonica
. Although the reflectance of the anthers of
C. japonica
seemed similar between the two species, the achromatic contrast and intensity of the anther of
C. rusticana
were higher. Bees would have difficulty in the detection of
C. japonica
due to these color factors ( Rohde et al., 2013 ; van der Kooi et al., 2019 ), which probably accounts for the selective behavior of bumblebees in
C. rusticana
vs
C. japonica
and the quite low frequency of bee visitation, even in
C. japonica
vs
C. japonica
( Fig. 2 ).

In the UVS-avian tetrahedral color space, the petal loci of
C. japonica
are located closer to the tetrahedral vertex representing the red receptor. This is in an agreement with the distribution of loci for trochilophilous flowers ( de Camargo et al., 2019 ; Chen et al., 2020 ). In the RNL model, all Δ S of petals and anthers exceeded 1 JND (the theoretical discrimination threshold), where the two colors are indistinguishable ( Siddiqi et al., 2004 ). Contrary to the color vision of bees, the UV-absorbing feature of
C. japonica
petals was found to enhance Δ S in UVS-bird vision. The UV-absorbing petals of
C. japonica
with higher avian-chromatic contrast may provide an advantage in attracting
Z. japonicus
.

Furthermore, fluorescence analyses revealed another difference between
C. rusticana
and
C. japonica
: the anther of entomophilous
C. rusticana
emits UV-induced blue fluorescence from its epidermis of the anther wall, while ornithophilous
C. japonica
does not ( Fig. 1 ). The emission spectra ( λ Em 427 nm ) of the anthers overlaps the sensitivity curve of pollinators such as bees, flies, and beetles ( Menzel and Blakers, 1976 ; Peitsch et al., 1992 ). The fluorescence of
C. rusticana
anthers may serve as a visual cue to attract foraging bees. The anther of
C. × intermedia
also showed the same λ Em as that of
C. rusticana
with an intermediate intensity between that of
C. rusticana
and
C. japonica
( Fig. 5A and B ), suggesting that the anther fluorescence is a quantitative trait under polygenic control. The pollination vector of
C. × intermedia
are currently unknown, but it may be partially entomophilous.

Several fluorescent compounds having caffeoyl and feruloyl moieties as the fluorophore have been previously identified from anther and pollen of seven species representing five families (eg. Mori et al., 2018 ), but 1 and 2 were isolated for the first time from anthers. The emission spectra of 1 and 2 almost corresponded to that of
C. rusticana
anther ( Fig. 5A, C ), indicating that the fluorescent compounds are responsible for the blue fluorescence of anther epidermis. The anther of
C. rusticana
contained significantly higher amounts of 1 (44.0-fold) and 2 (8.3-fold) than that of
C. japonica
. Anthranilate is biosynthesized from chorismate by anthranilate synthase (Romero et al., 1995) and is a precursor of L-tryptophan, leading the syntheses of many specialized metabolites such as auxins, phytoalexins, and alkaloids ( Radwanski and Last, 1995 ). In the speciation process of
C. rusticana
and
C. japonica
, the regulation of the tryptophan biosynthetic pathway may have been altered. Compounds 1 and 2 could be used as chemotaxonomic markers in the genus
Camellia
. Anthranilic acid and its ester derivatives are known as repellents for several bird species (e.g., Clark et al., 1991 ). For example, 2 triggers pain receptors in the avian trigeminal nerve and significantly suppresses the fluid intake level of the European starlings (
Sturnus vulgaris
) with concentration of 0.25% (w/v) ( Mason et al., 1989 ). The abundance of 1 and
2 in
the anther of
C. rusticana
may be implicated in the low rate of visitation to
C. rusticana
flowers by
Z. japonicus
.

In summary, the color and blue fluorescence of
C. rusticana
flowers appeals to bees but not birds; whereas the chromatic contrast of
C . japonica
flowers may appeal to birds and not bees. Our results support the bee avoidance hypothesis ( Grant, 1966 ; Raven, 1972 );
C. japonica
seemed to exclude antagonistic visitor, bees. The pollinator difference between
C . rusticana
and
C. japonica
may have been caused by the following factors ( Abe et al., 2021 ): the conspicuousness of
C. rusticana
to bees ( de Camargo et al., 2019 ), the indiscriminability of
C. japonica
against leaf background to bees, and possibly ( Chen et al., 2020 ) the avoidance of birds from
C. rusticana
. These characteristics may have been one of the driving forces behind the speciation by pollinator shift of the genus
Camellia
(i.e. from insects to birds). The involvement of olfactory and other cues influencing the pollinator difference requires further studies. Studies on the relative pollen removal and deposition abilities of bee and bird pollinators for different
Camellia species
would be also necessary. Comprehensive interspecific comparative studies of floral traits and pollinators and detailed molecular phylogenetic analysis will shed light on the pollinator shift and evolution in the genus
Camellia
.

Medium pressure liquid chromatography (MPLC) was performed on a Reveleris X2 system (Büchi, Flawil, Switzerland ) using FlashPure Select Silica 4.0 g cartridge (Büchi) with the following conditions: detection, λ Abs 254 nm ; flow rate, 12.0 mL min 1 . HPLC was performed on a system consisting of a PU-2089 Plus pump (Jasco, Tokyo , Japan ), UV-2075 Plus detector (Jasco), LC-Net II/ADC interface box (Jasco), SSC-2120 column oven (Senshu Scientific, Tokyo ), and a YMC-Triart C18 column (φ 10 mm × 250 mm ; YMC, Kyoto , Japan ) at the following conditions: detection, λ Abs 254 nm ; flow rate, 2.4 mL min 1 ; column oven, 25 ◦ C.

ESI-TOF MS was performed on an Acquity UPLC system (Waters, MA, USA ) coupled to a mass spectrometer. Mass spectra were acquired with LCT-Premier XE (Waters) equipped with an electron spray ionization (ESI) source operated in the positive ion mode eluting with 0.1% FA in 50% MeCN aq. at a flow rate of 0.2 mL min 1 . The mass detector parameters were set as follows: capillary voltage, 2.7 kV; cone voltage, 15 V; source temperature, 62 ◦ C; desolvation temperature, 350 ◦ C; cone gas, 50 L h 1 ; and desolvation gas, 70 L h 1 . Leucin-Enkephalin was used as a lockmass reference compound ([M + H ] + m / z 556.2771). Data processing was performed using MassLynx version 4.1 (Waters).

NMR spectra of 1 and 2 were measured in methanol-
d 4
(Sigma- Aldrich, MO, USA ) on a JNM-ECA500 (500 MHz; JEOL, Tokyo , Japan ). Data were processed with MestReNova version 14.2.1 (Mestrelab Research, Santiago de Compostela, Spain ).

Buds of
Camellia (Theaceae)
plants were collected at the following areas in Niigata , Japan , in March 2018 and February 2022 :
C. rusticana Honda
from seven trees at Kagitori (
37 ◦ 34 ′ 24.9 ′′ N
,
139 ◦ 23 ′ 15.1 ′′ E
) and Ninoji (
37 ◦ 54 ′ 17.1 ′′ N
,
139 ◦ 27 ′ 57.8 ′′ E
);
C. japonica
L. from four trees at Maze (
37 ◦ 43 ′ 42.9 ′′ N
,
138 ◦ 47 ′ 28.8 ′′ E
); and
C. × intermedia
from four trees at Niitsu (
37 ◦ 42 ′ 55.6 ′′ N
,
139 ◦ 5 ′ 28.3 ′′ E
). After the buds flowered in the laboratory, they were photographed within hours and immediately used for further experiments.

Flowers were photographed with an EOS 60D camera (Canon, Tokyo , Japan ) equipped with an EF-S 60 mm F2.8 MACRO USM lens (Canon). Anthers and pollen grains were observed with a stereomicroscope SMZ-1500 (Nikon, Tokyo , Japan ). Fluorescent lamps HGX FHF32EX (32 W; NEC lighting, Tokyo , Japan ) were used for white light illumination, and two Handy UV Lamps LUV-16 ( λ Max 365 nm , 16 W; ASONE, Osaka , Japan ) were used for UV illumination.

A behavioral two-choice assay was carried out between 11:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. on three sunny days during
March 2022
in the Yagami Campus of Keio University, Japan (
35 ◦ 33 ′ 19.6 ′′ N
,
139 ◦ 39 ′ 16.6 ′′ E
) using the Japanese native bumblebee,
Bombus ignitus
, as a model pollinator. A queenright colony containing approx. 300 flower-naïve workers were obtained from Arysta LifeScience ( Tokyo , Japan ) and bred in a hive. Dried pollen and sugar water were fed to the bumblebees before and between the tests. The hive was placed in a flight-cage measuring W0.7 × D0.7 × H 0.7 m , in which the assay was performed. The test match was
C. rusticana
vs
C. japonica
, and the control matches
C. rusticana
vs
C. rusticana
and
C. japonica
vs
C. japonica
. For each plant, a branch (approx. 30 cm ) bearing two fresh flowers was placed in an Erlenmeyer flask. The branches were replaced every test. Three
C. rusticana
and
C. japonica
plants were used. The number of bee landings on flowers of each plant was counted for 10 min (visits per 10 min), and each match was repeated eight times. Data are presented as mean ± SD (n = 8). The position of two plants was switched every tests to prevent confounding of the results by any position preference of the bees.

Diffuse reflectance spectra of dehisced anthers with pollen, petals (adaxial side), and leaves (adaxial side) were measured from 300 nm to 700 nm using a V-670 spectrometer (Jasco, Tokyo , Japan ) equipped with an integrating sphere unit ISN-723 (Jasco). The samples were measured in an FPA-810 powder sample cell (Jasco). Spectralon® (Labsphere, NH, USA ) was used as a white standard. Data were processed with Spectra Manager version 2.10.01 (Jasco).

The intensity of the secondary peak was expressed as a ratio, k , calculated by dividing the intensity of the secondary peak by the intensity of the peak in whole spectrum, following Chen et al. (2020) . UV-A absorbance was evaluated by calculating the area under the spectral curve of reflectance ( AUCRef ) from 300 to 400 nm . Data are expressed as mean ± SD of three biological replications.

heading.emphasis: 5.6. Visual model of pollinators and color variables

subSection.paragraph:
The color loci of each petal and anther in the pollinator’ s perceptual color space were computed by entering their diffuse reflectance spectra into the R ( R Core Team, 2021 ) package pavo version 2.7.0 ( Maia et al., 2019 ). The CIE D65 daylight irradiance spectrum was used as a model of daylight irradiance. An averaged reflectance spectrum calculated from leaves of
C. rusticana
and
C. japonica
was assumed as the background of the petal and anther.

To model trichromatic bee vision, the loci were plotted in the bee color hexagon space ( CH model; Chittka, 1992 ). Since the photopigments underlying trichromatic vision are conserved in Hymenoptera , the spectral sensitivity of
A. mellifera
was used as a model ( Peitsch et al., 1992 ). The hexagon was divided into six categories based on their stimulation of honeybee photoreceptors: UV, UV–Blue, Blue, Blue–- Green, Green, and UV–Green. Bee-achromatic contrast, also referred as green contrast, corresponds to the green photoreceptor excitation adapted to the background, which was calculated as the absolute value of |
0.5 E
(G)| as per Spaethe et al. (2001) . Bee-chromatic contrast was evaluated by the Euclidean distance between the flower locus and the hexagon center, representing the leaf background ( Chittka, 1992 ). Color intensity was calculated as a sum of photoreceptor excitations ( Spaethe et al., 2001 ). Spectral purity values in the hexagon model were calculated as the distance between the flower locus and the hexagon center in relation to the distance between the maximal spectral purity locus and the center ( Lunau et al., 1996 ; Chittka and Kevan, 2005 ).

For the tetrachromatic vision of
Z. japonicus
, the color loci were projected in the bird tetrahedron vision space ( Endler and Mielke, 2005 ). Diurnal birds have at least two discrete types of color vision: ultraviolet-sensitive (UVS) and violet sensitive (VS) ( Cuthill et al., 2000 ). Since
Z. japonicus
falls into a UV sensitive (UVS) type ( Odeen and Hastad, 2010 ), the spectral sensitivity of an averaged UVS-avian was used ( Maia et al., 2019 ). The distance from the flower locus to the tetrahedron achromatic center was calculated as spectral purity ( Stoddard and Prum, 2011 ). Achromatic (Δ L ) and chromatic contrasts (Δ S ) against a leaf background were calculated in the receptor noise-limited model (RNL model; Vorobyev and Osorio, 1998 ). Δ L was calculated based on the double cone responsible for chromatic processing, according to Siddiqi et al. (2004) . Δ S was obtained by weighting the Euclidean distance of the photoreceptor quantum catches by the Weber fraction of the cones. The Weber fraction ( ω ) was assumed to be 0.1 in the LWS mechanism, based on the empirically estimated value from the Pekin robin (
Leiothrix lutea
) ( Maier, 1992 ; Olsson et al., 2018 ). Photoreceptor abundance of the cone types was estimated to be 1:2:2:4 for the UVS: SWS:MWS:LWS, according to those of
L. lutea ( Vorobyev and Osorio, 1998 )
. Δ S was expressed in just noticeable difference (JND), where 1 JND is the theoretical threshold of color discrimination for stimuli viewed simultaneously under ideal viewing conditions ( Vorobyev et al., 2001 ).

The fluorescence spectra of the anthers with pollen were measured with an FP-8300 spectrofluorometer equipped with an FPA-810 powder sample cell block (Jasco). The fluorescence spectra of 1 , 2 , and anthranilic acid in MeOH were measured in a quartz cuvette (path length, 10 mm ) using an RF-6000 spectrofluorometer (Shimadzu, Kyoto , Japan ). Excitation and emission spectra were measured from 300 nm to 600 nm . The area under spectral curve of emission ( AUCEm ) from 300 to 600 nm was calculated to evaluate the fluorescence intensity, which was expressed as mean ± SD .

heading.emphasis: 5.8. Isolation and quantification of fluorescent compounds

document.paragraph:
Pollen-bearing
C. rusticana
anthers ( 4.2 g FW) were soaked in 100 mL of MeOH. The extract was filtered with a qualitative filter paper ADVANTEC No. 2 (Toyo Roshi Kaisha, Tokyo , Japan ) to yield an oily, yellow residue ( 0.5 g ) which was partitioned between EtOAc and H 2 O. The material from the aqueous layer was purified by silica gel column chromatography (φ22.0 mm × 80.0 mm) eluting with 10.0 mL of CHCl 3 –MeOH (0, 10, 20, 30, 50, 70, and 100% MeOH) for each fraction. The fraction eluting with 30% MeOH was subjected to preparative HPLC (eluent, 45% MeOH aq. containing 0.1% TFA). The component eluting at t R 8.3 min was collected and concentrated to give fluorescent compound 1 (1.0 mg) as a colorless solid. The material from the organic layer was flash-chromatographed on silica cartridge with a gradient solvent system of n -hexane–EtOAc (0–10 min, 0–20%; 10–15 min, 50% EtOAc). The component eluting at t R 5.0–6.7 min (Fr. 1) was collected and concentrated to yield a yellow solid residue. Fr. 1 was subjected to preparative HPLC (eluent, 70% MeOH aq. containing 0.1% TFA). The component eluting at t R 11.2 min was collected and concentrated to give fluorescent compound 2 ( 0.6 mg ).

Quantification was performed with HPLC. The amount of the fluorescent compounds in the extract was calculated with a calibration curve between the weight and peak area, using standards. The quantification was conducted with three individual extracts for each species, which were expressed as mean ± SD.

subSection.paragraph: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
Data will be made available on request.

We thank Harue Abe for valuable discussion on the ecology of
Camellia
; Hiroki Kohama for sampling of
Camellia
plants; and Yuta Yamauchi for illustrations. This research did not receive any specific grant from funding agencies in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2022.113559.
